{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2984888,"name":"Jamory","username":"Jamory","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/85f322/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-03T20:53:14.099Z","cooked":"

The Outliers, 5687, offer their 2021 CAD models, which can be found here: A Fond Farewell to GrabCAD Workbench - GrabCAD Blog

There are 3 models in the folder. The first is our 2021 robot, which is not quite a complete CAD model as a result of the limitations of being remote. The second model is a basic chassis bot we design as a platform to test our new differential swerves. And the third is a model of our differential swerve module, which we designed this past year. We are planning on a more complete release of this design after we complete some more testings and feel confident with the design. Our design objectives were the following:

  • Keep COG as low as possible
  • Keep top below the standard bumper height of 7”
  • Maintain a 1.5” ground clearance
  • Use as many COTS and 3D printed parts as possible

We do have access to a water jet, so we were able to fabricate our own custom gears. The modules are built around Swerve Drive Specialties Main Plates and use West Coast Products Bevel gears. The translation (wheels) ratio is 6.47:1 and the rotation (steering) ratio is 9.2:1. We will be testing these modules this year, and will make a more complete report at that point. For anyone that is interested we are happy to answer any questions and share all we have.

5687 dif swerve v33065×1707 383 KB

5687 dif swerve v3 cutaway 13065×1707 419 KB

I like the wiring harness block. Looks like replacing a module would be pretty straightforward, at least electrically. We’ve been trying to figure out some sort of mechanical quick disconnect to swap out whole swerve modules between matches while still being rigid and reliable. Can’t wait to see these in action!

Thanks, We realized it would be important to easily swap a whole module to make repairs, and wanted something that could be swapped with just a hex driver. We decided this year to make the switch to Wago’s. The Wago holder in the back holds all the electrical connections, has built-in wire strain relief and doesn’t take up much additional space. So far it has worked pretty well but probably needs another iteration or two.
